html_title: Predicting NBA Games with R and hoopR (Win Probabilities + Heatmaps) | R-bloggers
meta_description: If you love sports analytics, this post will show you how to predict NBA matchups using real ESPN data and the R ecosystem ‚Äî specifically hoopR, tidyverse, and ggplot2. We‚Äôll use a simple Poisson model to simulate thousands of possible scores, compute win probabilities, and visualize expected outcomes for any matchup ‚Äî all inside R. [‚Ä¶] The post Predicting NBA Games with R and hoopR (Win Probabilities + Heatmaps) appeared first on R Programming Books.

data.main_text:
Predicting NBA Games with R and hoopR (Win Probabilities + Heatmaps)
Posted on
October 8, 2025
by
rprogrammingbooks
in
R bloggers
| 0 Comments
[This article was first published on
Blog - R Programming Books
, and kindly contributed to
R-bloggers
].  (You can report issue about the content on this page
here
)
Want to share your content on R-bloggers?
click here
if you have a blog, or
here
if you don't.
If you love
sports analytics
, this post will show you how to predict NBA matchups using real ESPN data and the R ecosystem ‚Äî specifically
hoopR
,
tidyverse
, and
ggplot2
.
We‚Äôll use a simple
Poisson model
to simulate thousands of possible scores, compute
win probabilities
, and visualize expected outcomes for any matchup ‚Äî all inside R.
What you‚Äôll build
A fully reproducible NBA prediction pipeline that:
Aggregates player box scores into
team-level points for/against
Estimates
expected points
using recent games and a Poisson model
Simulates 100,000 possible scorelines
Produces three key visuals:
Win probabilities
Scoreline heatmap
Expected team points
Why this approach?
Transparent
‚Äì You can inspect every assumption and adjust parameters.
Fast
‚Äì Pulls ESPN game data directly with
hoopR
.
Flexible
‚Äì Works for any season or teams with minimal edits.
Full R code
You can copy and run this entire block in RStudio.
Change the
HOME_TEAM
and
AWAY_TEAM
codes to simulate any matchup.
library(tidyverse)
library(hoopR)
library(ggplot2)
SEASON <- 2024
HOME_TEAM <- ‚ÄúBOS‚Äù
AWAY_TEAM <- ‚ÄúDEN‚Äù
N_GAMES <- 15
HOME_ADV <- 0.06
MAX_POINTS <- 150
pb <- hoopR::load_nba_player_box(seasons = SEASON)
dnp_cols <- intersect(c(‚Äúdid_not_play‚Äù,‚Äùdid_not_dress‚Äù,‚Äùnot_with_team‚Äù), names(pb)) if (length(dnp_cols)) pb <- pb %>% filter(if_all(all_of(dnp_cols), is.na))
team_pts <- pb %>%
group_by(game_id, game_date, season_type, team_abbreviation) %>%
summarise(pts_for = sum(points, na.rm = TRUE), .groups = ‚Äúdrop‚Äù)
team_games <- team_pts %>%
inner_join(team_pts, by = ‚Äúgame_id‚Äù, suffix = c(‚Äú‚Äù, ‚Äú_opp‚Äù)) %>%
filter(team_abbreviation != team_abbreviation_opp) %>%
group_by(game_id, team_abbreviation) %>% slice_head(n = 1) %>% ungroup() %>%
transmute(
game_id, game_date, season_type, team_abbreviation,
opponent_abbreviation = team_abbreviation_opp,
pts_for, pts_against = pts_for_opp
) %>%
filter(season_type == 2)
team_recent_means <- function(df, team, n = 15) { df %>% filter(team_abbreviation == team) %>%
arrange(game_date) %>% slice_tail(n = n) %>%
summarise(off_avg = mean(pts_for, na.rm = TRUE),
def_avg = mean(pts_against, na.rm = TRUE))
}
home_stats <- team_recent_means(team_games, HOME_TEAM, N_GAMES)
away_stats <- team_recent_means(team_games, AWAY_TEAM, N_GAMES)
home_stats[is.na(home_stats)] <- 113
away_stats[is.na(away_stats)] <- 113
lambda_home <- home_stats$off_avg * (away_stats$def_avg / mean(c(home_stats$def_avg, away_stats$def_avg)))
lambda_away <- away_stats$off_avg * (home_stats$def_avg / mean(c(home_stats$def_avg, away_stats$def_avg)))
lambda_home <- lambda_home * (1 + HOME_ADV)
lambda_home <- max(lambda_home, 95); lambda_away <- max(lambda_away, 95)
set.seed(42); S <- 100000 h <- rpois(S, lambda_home); a <- rpois(S, lambda_away) p_home <- mean(h > a); p_away <- mean(h < a); p_tie <- mean(h == a)
probs <- tibble(
outcome = factor(c(‚ÄúHome‚Äù,‚ÄùAway‚Äù), levels = c(‚ÄúHome‚Äù,‚ÄùAway‚Äù)),
prob = c(p_home, p_away),
label = scales::percent(c(p_home, p_away), accuracy = 0.1)
)
p1 <- ggplot(probs, aes(outcome, prob, fill = outcome)) +
geom_col(width = 0.6, color = ‚Äúblack‚Äù) +
geom_text(aes(label = label), vjust = -0.35, size = 5) +
scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent_format(accuracy = 1),
expand = expansion(mult = c(0, .08))) +
scale_fill_manual(values = c(‚ÄúHome‚Äù=‚Äù#1B9E77‚Ä≥,‚ÄùAway‚Äù=‚Äù#D95F02‚Äù)) +
labs(title = sprintf(‚Äú%s vs %s ‚Äî Win Probabilities‚Äù, HOME_TEAM, AWAY_TEAM),
subtitle = sprintf(‚ÄúRecent %d games ‚Ä¢ Independent Poisson model‚Äù, N_GAMES),
x = NULL, y = ‚ÄúProbability‚Äù,
caption = ‚ÄúData: ESPN via hoopR‚Äù) +
theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +
theme(legend.position=‚Äùnone‚Äù, plot.title=element_text(face=‚Äùbold‚Äù))
grid <- expand.grid(H = 70:MAX_POINTS, A = 70:MAX_POINTS)
grid$prob <- dpois(grid$H, lambda_home) * dpois(grid$A, lambda_away)
p2 <- ggplot(grid, aes(H, A, fill = prob)) +
geom_tile() +
scale_fill_viridis_c(option = ‚ÄúC‚Äù, trans = ‚Äúsqrt‚Äù) +
labs(title = sprintf(‚Äú%s vs %s ‚Äî Scoreline Heatmap (Prob.)‚Äù, HOME_TEAM, AWAY_TEAM),
x = sprintf(‚ÄúHome points ‚Äî %s‚Äù, HOME_TEAM),
y = sprintf(‚ÄúAway points ‚Äî %s‚Äù, AWAY_TEAM),
fill = ‚ÄúProb.‚Äù) +
theme_minimal(base_size = 14)
expected_pts <- tibble(team = c(HOME_TEAM, AWAY_TEAM),
exp_pts = c(lambda_home, lambda_away))
p3 <- ggplot(expected_pts, aes(reorder(team, exp_pts), exp_pts, fill = team)) +
geom_col(width = 0.6, color = ‚Äúblack‚Äù) +
geom_text(aes(label = round(exp_pts, 1)), vjust = -0.35, size = 5) +
coord_flip() +
scale_fill_manual(values = c(‚Äú#1B9E77‚Äù, ‚Äú#D95F02‚Äù)) +
labs(title=‚ÄùExpected Team Points (Poisson Œª)‚Äù, x=‚ÄùTeam‚Äù, y=‚ÄùPoints‚Äù) +
theme_minimal(base_size = 14) + theme(legend.position=‚Äùnone‚Äù)
print(p1); print(p2); print(p3)
How to read the charts
Win Probabilities
Each bar shows the simulated probability of a win for each team based on their offensive and defensive averages.
Scoreline Heatmap
Darker cells represent more likely combinations of final scores.
Expected Points (Œª)
Poisson means for each team ‚Äî useful as predicted points for betting or fantasy analytics.
Limitations
Assumes independent Poisson scoring (ignores game pace, possessions, and correlations).
No adjustments for player injuries or rest days.
A simple model ‚Äî great for demonstration, not gambling advice.
The post
Predicting NBA Games with R and hoopR (Win Probabilities + Heatmaps)
appeared first on
R Programming Books
.
Related
To
leave a comment
for the author, please follow the link and comment on their blog:
Blog - R Programming Books
.

data.main_html:
Predicting NBA Games with R and hoopR (Win Probabilities + Heatmaps)

Posted on October 8, 2025 by rprogrammingbooks in R bloggers | 0 Comments

[This article was first published on Blog - R Programming Books, and kindly contributed to R-bloggers]. (You can report issue about the content on this page here)
Want to share your content on R-bloggers? click here if you have a blog, or here if you don't.

If you love sports analytics, this post will show you how to predict NBA matchups using real ESPN data and the R ecosystem ‚Äî specifically hoopR, tidyverse, and ggplot2.

We‚Äôll use a simple Poisson model to simulate thousands of possible scores, compute win probabilities, and visualize expected outcomes for any matchup ‚Äî all inside R.

What you‚Äôll build

A fully reproducible NBA prediction pipeline that:

  • Aggregates player box scores into team-level points for/against
  • Estimates expected points using recent games and a Poisson model
  • Simulates 100,000 possible scorelines
  • Produces three key visuals:
    1. Win probabilities
    2. Scoreline heatmap
    3. Expected team points

Why this approach?

  • Transparent ‚Äì You can inspect every assumption and adjust parameters.
  • Fast ‚Äì Pulls ESPN game data directly with hoopR.
  • Flexible ‚Äì Works for any season or teams with minimal edits.

Full R code

You can copy and run this entire block in RStudio.
Change the HOME_TEAM and AWAY_TEAM codes to simulate any matchup.

library(tidyverse)
library(hoopR)
library(ggplot2)

SEASON <- 2024
HOME_TEAM <- ‚ÄúBOS‚Äù
AWAY_TEAM <- ‚ÄúDEN‚Äù
N_GAMES <- 15
HOME_ADV <- 0.06
MAX_POINTS <- 150

pb <- hoopR::load_nba_player_box(seasons = SEASON)

dnp_cols <- intersect(c(‚Äúdid_not_play‚Äù,‚Äùdid_not_dress‚Äù,‚Äùnot_with_team‚Äù), names(pb)) if (length(dnp_cols)) pb <- pb %>% filter(if_all(all_of(dnp_cols), is.na))

team_pts <- pb %>%
group_by(game_id, game_date, season_type, team_abbreviation) %>%
summarise(pts_for = sum(points, na.rm = TRUE), .groups = ‚Äúdrop‚Äù)

team_games <- team_pts %>%
inner_join(team_pts, by = ‚Äúgame_id‚Äù, suffix = c(‚Äú‚Äù, ‚Äú_opp‚Äù)) %>%
filter(team_abbreviation != team_abbreviation_opp) %>%
group_by(game_id, team_abbreviation) %>% slice_head(n = 1) %>% ungroup() %>%
transmute(
game_id, game_date, season_type, team_abbreviation,
opponent_abbreviation = team_abbreviation_opp,
pts_for, pts_against = pts_for_opp
) %>%
filter(season_type == 2)

team_recent_means <- function(df, team, n = 15) { df %>% filter(team_abbreviation == team) %>%
arrange(game_date) %>% slice_tail(n = n) %>%
summarise(off_avg = mean(pts_for, na.rm = TRUE),
def_avg = mean(pts_against, na.rm = TRUE))
}

home_stats <- team_recent_means(team_games, HOME_TEAM, N_GAMES)
away_stats <- team_recent_means(team_games, AWAY_TEAM, N_GAMES)
home_stats[is.na(home_stats)] <- 113
away_stats[is.na(away_stats)] <- 113

lambda_home <- home_stats$off_avg * (away_stats$def_avg / mean(c(home_stats$def_avg, away_stats$def_avg)))
lambda_away <- away_stats$off_avg * (home_stats$def_avg / mean(c(home_stats$def_avg, away_stats$def_avg)))
lambda_home <- lambda_home * (1 + HOME_ADV)
lambda_home <- max(lambda_home, 95); lambda_away <- max(lambda_away, 95)

set.seed(42); S <- 100000 h <- rpois(S, lambda_home); a <- rpois(S, lambda_away) p_home <- mean(h > a); p_away <- mean(h < a); p_tie <- mean(h == a)

probs <- tibble(
outcome = factor(c(‚ÄúHome‚Äù,‚ÄùAway‚Äù), levels = c(‚ÄúHome‚Äù,‚ÄùAway‚Äù)),
prob = c(p_home, p_away),
label = scales::percent(c(p_home, p_away), accuracy = 0.1)
)

p1 <- ggplot(probs, aes(outcome, prob, fill = outcome)) +
geom_col(width = 0.6, color = ‚Äúblack‚Äù) +
geom_text(aes(label = label), vjust = -0.35, size = 5) +
scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent_format(accuracy = 1),
expand = expansion(mult = c(0, .08))) +
scale_fill_manual(values = c(‚ÄúHome‚Äù=‚Äù#1B9E77‚Ä≥,‚ÄùAway‚Äù=‚Äù#D95F02‚Äù)) +
labs(title = sprintf(‚Äú%s vs %s ‚Äî Win Probabilities‚Äù, HOME_TEAM, AWAY_TEAM),
subtitle = sprintf(‚ÄúRecent %d games ‚Ä¢ Independent Poisson model‚Äù, N_GAMES),
x = NULL, y = ‚ÄúProbability‚Äù,
caption = ‚ÄúData: ESPN via hoopR‚Äù) +
theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +
theme(legend.position=‚Äùnone‚Äù, plot.title=element_text(face=‚Äùbold‚Äù))

grid <- expand.grid(H = 70:MAX_POINTS, A = 70:MAX_POINTS)
grid$prob <- dpois(grid$H, lambda_home) * dpois(grid$A, lambda_away)
p2 <- ggplot(grid, aes(H, A, fill = prob)) +
geom_tile() +
scale_fill_viridis_c(option = ‚ÄúC‚Äù, trans = ‚Äúsqrt‚Äù) +
labs(title = sprintf(‚Äú%s vs %s ‚Äî Scoreline Heatmap (Prob.)‚Äù, HOME_TEAM, AWAY_TEAM),
x = sprintf(‚ÄúHome points ‚Äî %s‚Äù, HOME_TEAM),
y = sprintf(‚ÄúAway points ‚Äî %s‚Äù, AWAY_TEAM),
fill = ‚ÄúProb.‚Äù) +
theme_minimal(base_size = 14)

expected_pts <- tibble(team = c(HOME_TEAM, AWAY_TEAM),
exp_pts = c(lambda_home, lambda_away))
p3 <- ggplot(expected_pts, aes(reorder(team, exp_pts), exp_pts, fill = team)) +
geom_col(width = 0.6, color = ‚Äúblack‚Äù) +
geom_text(aes(label = round(exp_pts, 1)), vjust = -0.35, size = 5) +
coord_flip() +
scale_fill_manual(values = c(‚Äú#1B9E77‚Äù, ‚Äú#D95F02‚Äù)) +
labs(title=‚ÄùExpected Team Points (Poisson Œª)‚Äù, x=‚ÄùTeam‚Äù, y=‚ÄùPoints‚Äù) +
theme_minimal(base_size = 14) + theme(legend.position=‚Äùnone‚Äù)

print(p1); print(p2); print(p3)

How to read the charts

Win Probabilities
Each bar shows the simulated probability of a win for each team based on their offensive and defensive averages.

Scoreline Heatmap
Darker cells represent more likely combinations of final scores.

Expected Points (Œª)
Poisson means for each team ‚Äî useful as predicted points for betting or fantasy analytics.

Limitations

  • Assumes independent Poisson scoring (ignores game pace, possessions, and correlations).
  • No adjustments for player injuries or rest days.
  • A simple model ‚Äî great for demonstration, not gambling advice.

The post Predicting NBA Games with R and hoopR (Win Probabilities + Heatmaps) appeared first on R Programming Books.
